description:
Bacillus oleivorans is a species of Gram-positive, aerobic, spore-forming bacteria. It was first isolated from soil samples collected in Thailand. The cells of B. oleivorans are rod-shaped, approximately 0.5-0.7 μm in width and 1.5-3.0 μm in length.

One of the notable characteristics of B. oleivorans is its ability to degrade and utilize various types of oils and hydrocarbons as sole carbon and energy sources. This includes vegetable oils, mineral oils, and even some aromatic hydrocarbons. This metabolic capability makes B. oleivorans a potential candidate for bioremediation applications, particularly in the cleanup of oil spills and hydrocarbon-contaminated environments.

Taxonomically, B. oleivorans belongs to the genus Bacillus, which is a well-known group of bacteria known for their ability to form endospores, allowing them to survive in harsh environmental conditions. The species was first described and named in 2004 based on its unique physiological and biochemical characteristics.

Further research on B. oleivorans may provide insights into the mechanisms and enzymes involved in its oil-degrading capabilities, which could have important implications for environmental biotechnology and bioremediation strategies.
